Mobile banking in sub-Saharan Africa has outpaced traditional banking and improved access to finance. In 2018, mobile money transactions in sub-Saharan Africa were equivalent to 25% of GDP compared to 5% in the rest of the world. https://t.co/pL64j6tiTR #InvestInDigitalAfrica https://t.co/o6xa91mOFP

.@KGeorgieva will join @GLOBSEC, @Bruegel_org and @i_montaigne on Monday, June 15 at 10:30AM ET (4:30PM CET) for a conversation on fiscal stabilization and the role of international financial institutions in the post-#COVID19 era. https://t.co/xT3jrzFbrB #ResilientEconomies

Until #COVID19, #Bangladesh’s economy had been experiencing robust growth. But the crisis has dealt an economic blow. New IMF emergency financing will help #Bangladesh with recovery, including spending needs on health and social protection. Read more https://t.co/uFii1rbjCX https://t.co/NzPI0GsxPZ

Countries in #LatAm have been severely affected by #COVID19. Most have responded w/ policies focused on mitigating the spread of the virus and protecting the most vulnerable. At the IMF, we have approved 17 requests for emergency financing for the region. https://t.co/DTckucU7JL https://t.co/LN4gsU81gR

The growing digital divide is set to become one of the legacies of the #COVID19 crisis. What can policymakers do? A key priority is broadening the access of low-income households and small businesses to financial products. Find out more: https://t.co/dr0meoljJe https://t.co/7blicRXc0m

The IMF Executive Board today approved additional emergency funding of US$111.06 million to help #Rwanda finance #COVID19 health and economic efforts. This follows an earlier approval of US$109.4 million in April. https://t.co/SoaEYpR0Ya #IMFAfrica https://t.co/5bWQ7gRGoK

Our research shows that greater access to #finance & #technology is associated with higher intergenerational income mobility. We estimate a difference of 2-3 percentage-point of GDP growth between financially inclusive countries and less inclusive ones. https://t.co/dr0meoljJe https://t.co/NfgvSoTAwY

As attention turns to the post‑#COVID19 recovery, four policy pillars can help guide how countries #InvestInDigitalAfrica – infrastructure, policies, people and skills, and resilience to risks. https://t.co/pL64j6bHvh #IMFAfrica

The virus-related disruption to #education has left millions of children at risk of “learning poverty.” We need more investment in education, improving the quality of education, and access to life-long learning & re-skilling. Read @KGeorgieva’s #IMFblog https://t.co/dr0meoljJe https://t.co/VTL6ctnbjq

IMF's Chami at #VirtualCHOW: The ocean ecosystems are the most important carbon sinks in the world. Policy is needed to protect this natural asset and that starts with discussing legal protection. @marinesanctuary https://t.co/E0KqVgZfGl

DMD Zhang - We're gearing up efforts to help countries recover toward a better future, with guidance on:
✔️appropriate carbon prices 
✔️incentives for climate-resilient investment 
✔️climate risks & adaptation spending 
And speedy assistance when a natural disaster hits https://t.co/UnyKwFY4zr

The “Day After” can be greener & more sustainable if we keep the momentum on #climatechange—even as we are being challenged by #COVID19.
